title: Mason Mount's progress to England squad does not surprise me, says Gareth Southgate
text:
Mason Mount has been destined to become an England player since the age of 16, according to manager Gareth Southgate.

The midfielder is expected to be handed his first England start against Czech Republic in Prague on Friday. The 20-year-old has been in superb form for Chelsea after returning to Stamford Bridge from his loan at Derby County, but Southgate revealed he had been tracking Mount for four years.

Asked what had impressed him about Mount, Southgate said: “Exactly what I thought of him when I saw him playing for our Under-16s. He’s a quality player, an intelligent footballer, presses well, has a real eye for goal, good quality. So, nothing I’ve seen surprises me at all.

“We’ve had him marked as a player from the first time I saw him at St George’s Park. Chelsea would be the same on that, I think, but of course he’s now been able to have the opportunity to play in the Premier League and display that against top teams. I think you saw his penalty in the Super Cup, that was a nice cameo of what he’s about, really.”

With James Maddison pulling out of the squad due to illness, Mount is set to take his Chelsea team-mate Ross Barkley’s place in midfield. Mount is one of three Chelsea academy graduates in Southgate’s squad, along with striker Tammy Abraham and defender Fikayo Tomori. Another, Ruben Loftus-Cheek, would also have expected to have been included if not injured.
description: Mason Mount has been destined to become an England player since the age of 16, according to manager Gareth Southgate.
